comments.commentBody: With all of the real problems confronting us as a nation who give a rip about a basketball player/entertainer. If you don't like the guy don't watch him. If you are like me you wouldn't go to watch an NBA game if someone gave you the best seats in the house for free.

Lighten up?  C'mon, it's sports; it's supposed to be a passionate experience. People don't hate him for playing in another city as much as for the discourteous and arrogant way he left the city that loved him.

The Yankees have turned this into a PR nightmare for themselves.  Who's running the show?  Who's calling the shots?  They allow Jeter to run the show and call the shots and the Yankees have to backpedal and look foolish.  The Boss would not be proud.  He'd have grabbed hold of this thing, won the PR war and made Jeter seem  ungrateful and should relish the opportunity just to wear the uniform a couple more years.  Yea and the Boss wouldn't have started at 15 mil either.

Very simple: let Jeter see how much he'd get with another team. Then let the Yanks match that figure with some incentives for putting up the numbers in 2011. If the Captain doesn't agree, let him go Never happen, I know but c'mon, haven't we learned anything from the A-Rod fiasco? That way, Cash can throw outrageous offers at Cliff Lee, and keep getting us fans  to chow down on those outrageoisly priced hot dogs at the new Yankee Stadium. There's an analogy in here somewhere with those bad boys from the Street...

I am looking forward to the Yanks signing Jeter to 4 more years
at 20 million or so per.
This will diminish the Yankees.
An aging player who could not play his position is good for the
other teams the Yanks play.
And, less we forget - Jeter was NEVER the best at his position
in any of his years playing baseball.
In today's fair market he's worth - maybe - 3 million per year.
So, gi ahead and sign him.
He'll bat 216 with 7 home runs and 50 RBI's by the time his contract is up.
Go ahead....make our day.

It is outrageous. How much does one person need. It is just a game. People are losing their jobs and homes and a multimillionaire is unable to accept $15 million a year. Shame on all of you for debating this collective selfishness.

I've been against them caving, but hey I'd love to have a 37 year old SS, who's hitting 270 with less range than he had last year, so go O's....they might someday recover from letting Cal hang around too long too.

Give us a tax code that is one page long and therefore is too straightforward for tax loopholes, and a tax return that is the size of a postcard, and you, Mr. President, will get re-elected in 2012. If the Republicans vote it down, you will win by a landslide.

Thomas Huynh
Sonshi.com

comments.userDisplayName: Phil in the mountains of Kyushu
comments.commentBody:
Very funny, your concluding "if only President Obama would [fill-in-the-blank]."

"If" -- the biggest word in the English language.

I watched a little of your performance at the AEI debate, and one of the things you said was that you were palling around with Obama and some of his senior staff. I take you at your word on that, and it makes me think that the little scenario you've laid out here is pretty prescient. You may consider yourself to be the oracle of doom.

BTW, for you to call "Obama and his aides ... liberal or center-left pragmatists" is laughable. Obama and his aides are conservative and center-right flunkies. They will perpetuate, as you have divined with the aid of your insider knowledge, the long slide this country has been taking since the Reagan years toward becoming a feudal nation.

So congratulations, Brooks. Your side is winning. And 98 percent of us are losing. Soon it will be 99 percent. Better keep keeping on the good side of the rulers. You'll want to be in that top percentile, even if it's only as the court jester.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

You had me until >> Ryan is ... one of the most intellectually formidable members of Congress >>

Seriously? The same Ryan that said no country has ever benefited from devaluing its currency? {other than Britain, Sweden, Argentina ...|

The same Paul Ryan with the laughable budget plan that would have drastically INCREASED budget deficits, but apparently couldn't figure out the math?

The same Ryan that worships Ayn Rand?

Again with the visions. At least this time you got a glimpse of the obstreperous nature of Republican ideologues, and I hope you found it at least mildly irritating. Ryan seems to enjoy lowering taxes, but to compensate for lowered revenues he also enjoys dismantling social services. There is also his idea of a regressive consumption tax, so that lower and middle income people still wind up footing most of the bill. The rich can shelter and hoard their money, while the less well off, who must consume every penny they own, wind up paying disproportionately more. His vision focuses on the free market creating nebulous business opportunities, while he disparages (presumably with a sneer) the European model of taking care of people, most of whom are beyond their entrepreneurial years, and are mostly concerned with finding food, shelter, and medical care.

To reinforce this point you harp once again on “shifting resources from unproductive consumption to more productive investment.” Of course as our population ages, our individual lives become less profitable, and people enter the phase of what you call “unproductive consumption.” Apparently when granny can no longer work, you begrudge her the increasing cost of her upkeep. You say as much when you advocate shifting money from the affluent elderly to struggling youth. Of course one struggles in one’s youth in order to build wealth and hopefully enjoy a more affluent old age. I wonder if you ever have a vision in which you are no longer productive, and require a little of the support that most of us eventually need. Not everyone is a highly paid writer and speaker who has ample resources to last a lifetime. Or are you saying that as you enter your dotage you’ll gladly shift your money to some of those struggling youth? Now that would be a vision I’d like to hear about.

Does anyone in government ever read Mr. Brooks' columns?  Do they ever comment on his thoughts?  Do they discuss his and other columnists' ideas and give them critical discussion?  Does anything sensible that people outside government offer have any effect on policy?  Is there an answer to any of these questions?

Sadly, David, I think your observation made elsewhere this week that the GOP will oppose something that favors them 80-20, or 90-10, or even 99-1, if that one thing is perceived as being a win for Obama (the putative socialist).

I've lived in Europe. My grandpa was an ardent Swedish socialist. Obama is no socialist. He's a medium-liberal centrist with pragmatic tendencies.

But he has been fingered by Mitch McConnell for total failure and lockdown in the next Congress. And of course we, the citizens of these United States, will suffer the actual consequences of the GOP intransigence.

For whatever negetative impact people may think wilileaks has made.  To me it looks like 95% positive 5% negative.  Information and knowledge is power also.  Maybe when people are allowed the priviledge of being informed honestly and correct, any take it upon themselves to do so,they then have the power in their hands to change things.  Wikileaks just transferred a lot of that power to the ordinary individual out there, trying to make it a more level playing field out there.  Whatever anyone does in the name of justice and what is right will always be seen to be unpopular to the people it targets.  I believe the positives Wikileaks's publishing of secret documents far outweigh the negatives.

Why is the USA in Afghanistan and why did Obama expand operations there?
The US government has a long history of making allies of corrupt governments while taking its real friends for granted. Expect those old friends to be less friendly.

We have made the Karzai family billionaires.

That's all we have done in Afghanistan.

Late next year we'll declare "peace with honor," and withdraw. Trillions of dollars and many American lives too late.

What a disaster this whole adventure has been!

Bribery, extortion, and corruption? If someone had taken the time to learn a little about these countries, we might have been more careful with our toys. We are the wimpy kid who gets his lunch stolen every day on the way to school. Europe found America when they were trying to get to China without going through the middle east. They got tired of getting fleeced.

Assuming that Wikileaks is bad, I say there is no absolute bad for it already gave me a goose-bump of a picture of a world that we are trying to change through our money and our soldiers' lives. Change a way of life, a way of being, while the risk of being "contaminated" is not to exclude. Is it not clear that their leaders need some stability through the west's involvement so that they can concentrate on their filthy dealings? Obviously, we can not eradicate their mondus vivendi, we can only wonder if everything we have done, everything, was worth it. We are already in utopia territory.
These Wikileak cables expose a wealth of truth we Americans need to know. The truth shall make us free.

Maybe i am missing something but how is this different than the US.  Have you looked around lately, highways to nowhere (go to West Virginia or Pennsylvania, WV is particularly bad, interstates that nobody drives on and end nowhere, and that is not an exaggeration.  How did the term "Pay to Play" come about?  I worked with earmarks when I was in the military and many if not most are nothing but graft and bribery.  The New York times did an article about how senators and congressmen's wealth usually dramatically increases after they come in office, is it just that they get that much wiser about making investments?  Of course a lot of our corruption is legalized, like earmarks and campagin contributions.  Why aren't campaign contributions anonymous, no reason for them to not be other than you can't receive a payoff?  Look at Darleen A. Druyun  (not sure I spelled it right), former Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for acquisition who shoveled billions to Boeing for jobs for family and herself, among other things, and got nine months in jail?  Go try to committ an unarmed robbery of a bank for $100 and see if you only get nine months.  What about Senator Randy Duke Cunningham who shoveled unbelievable amounts of money to defense contractors for gifts and bribes (he got 10 years).  Look at Cheney being paid 36 million a year by Halliburton while he was VP, but of course they got no special consideration, right!

The parallels with Vietnam abound. (wouldn't you love to read the cables about South Vietnam's corrupt government/army?)

Even more so, is the more generalizable problems of "one upmanship" in traditional societies/cultures: Might makes Right, Family is Everything.

More and more, I suspect the respect for "the rule of law" stems from the Magna Carta. The West had "The Middle Ages" and "the Dark Age" aka "The Inquisition" when religious law rule all of society. It's no different than these theocratic Islamic societies.

I'm no longer counted in the unemployment statistics. I maxed out at 99 weeks and took a crumby hourly job at one-third my former salary -- no benefits. I have an MBA from a top tier school and an impressive resume. But I am also 55 years old. So I guess I should be grateful to be employed at all. How many are in positions similar to mine? How are we statistically accounted for?

"What am I unable to fathom is how backward the rail network is in this country."

We had passenger trains before, which explains the ornate stations you can find in many American cities. The bus system was also popular. They fell by the wayside as the prosperity of the nation grew. People preferred the freedom of the automobile or the speed of the airplane.

The United States does have the best freight rail system in the world.
Let's go Orange!!
